newsitem.title: USA: British Airways plans to expand JFK terminal.
newsitem.headline: British Airways plans to expand JFK terminal.

text.p: British Airways Plc said Thursday it planned to invest $100 million to expand its terminal at New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport and improve roadway access.
The $100 million investment is in addition to the $17 billion in spending planned for the United States over the next five years, the airline said.
"As our operations continue to grow in the U.S. and our alliance with American Airlines moves closer, so does our investment in America," said British Airways Chief Executive Robert Ayling.

Ayling said he remained confident a proposed trans-Atlantic alliance with American will be approved this summer, but British Air could reject the alliance if regulators required the airlines to pay a burdensome price, such as disposing of a large number of airport slots at London's Heathrow airport or some U.S. airports.
"If the terms are so penal that they are not in our commercial interest, we will say no," Ayling said at a press conference here to announce the Kennedy expension project.

Construction on the Kennedy terminal expansion will begin this summer, with completion set for mid-1999. A new roadway connecting local expressways to the terminal's access roads will be finished by mid-2000, British Airways said.
The expanded terminal will feature larger check-in areas, new lounges and a shopping plaza and "leisure centre." The design also includes a station for a proposed rail link to Manhattan.
British Airways said the expansion was not contingent on the approval of its proposed alliance with American. American Airlines, the No. 2 U.S. carrier, is a unit of Fort Worth, Texas-based AMR Corp.

"It's a happy coincidence that American's terminal is next to ours," Ayling said. If the proposed alliance is approved, British Airways said it will work with American to coordinate service between the two terminals.

Ayling said he did not know if American would move its facilities into the expanded British Airways building, since the space is now shared by United Airlines, a unit of Chicago-based UAL Corp. and the nation's largest carrier. United has been one of several competitors that have been critical of the proposed British Airways-American alliance.
British Airways said it was not aware if United planned to remain a tenant in the building. United representatives could not be immediately reached for comment.

"If United remains as a tenant that of course would led to one set of conclusions. If they left as a tenant, then we could use the whole of our terminal with American for our trans-Atlantic routes," Ayling said.
